message:
Media release

Clive Palmer extends hand of friendship to Citic Limited

Mineralogy was ready, willing and able to listen to Citic Limited on how it could assist the Chinese company with its Sino Iron Project in Western Australia, Clive Palmer said today.
 
Mr Palmer confirmed he had written to Citic Limited suggesting a meeting to resolve any matters that were affecting the project.
 
"I am happy to travel to Perth to meet the Chairman of Citic Limited to address first hand if anything needs to be done to ensure the success of the Sino Iron Project,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
Mr Palmer has released the letter that Mineralogy forwarded to the Chairman of Citic Limited.
 
"I hope the Chairman will take the time to meet with me personally to discuss all matters Citic Limited is concerned with and how we can assist Citic in achieving its commercial objectives.
 
"We can achieve much more by working together for the people of Western Australia and China.
 
“As Winston Churchill once said: To jaw-jaw is always better than to war-war.
 
Mr Palmer said Mineralogy was open to do whatever was required to support Western Australia and the Western Australian community.
 
"I sincerely hope the Chairman of Citic Limited will accept my invitation to meet in Perth so we can jointly move the Sino Iron Project forward.
 
"Together we can achieve the extraordinary,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
ENDS

message:
Citic Limited Releases  Fake News

“The recent statements by the Chairman of Citic Limited that the Sino Iron Project may be closed is designed to intimidate Australian Courts and interfering with Australia independent Justice System.” The Chairman of Mineralogy Clive Palmer stated in Brisbane today.

“While the Chairman of Citic Limited makes such false statements in Australia he does not make them to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange which he is required to do by law if they were true.”

“Mineralogy has approved the Sino Iron Project as has the State of Western Australia in proposals submitted in 2006. The rational for the Chairman of Citic Limited statement has no merit.  It is just a response the Western Australian court orders which in effect require Citic Limited to pay over $100,000,000 on an interim basis pending a final trial in June 2017.

Mineralogy has granted the Sino Iron project the use of land sufficient for 3.9 million tonnes of stockpiles at the port of Cape Preston which has been approved for that purpose by the Western Australian government under section 45(c) of the EPA act. Sino Iron is producing less than 14 million tonnes of concentrate a year no more than (8%) of annual output is required in a port stockpile. Sino Iron has land for sufficient stockpiles for over 40 million tonnes of concentrate Production each year.”

Mr Palmer stated “The Chairman of Citic Limited continues to lie to the Australian people seeking to gain a commercial advantage and threaten Australia’s independence by manipulating public opinion . The Public Relations consultants for Sino Iron continual to distribute Fake News that the Australian press do not properly scrutinise. This Fake News in essence is a foreign governments propaganda designed to scare and mislead Australians and their elected representatives..”

“Since January 2016 the price of iron ore has more than doubled. Following the Western Australian Supreme Court ordering Citic parties to pay Mineralogy US$6 a tonne on future exports of concentrate, Sino Iron’s revenue has increased by more than $500 million dollars a year from January 2016 after deducting the $6 payment. The Chairman of Citic Limited says he may close the project down.  Why? Because Citic is earning an extra $500 million a year? 

The chairman of Citic speaks with a forked tongue. The Chinese Government owned company should stop misleading the Australian people and respect them and our Legal system and ways of doing business in Australia if Chinese State Owned companies want continued to access Australian resources.” 

Mr Palmer went on to say. “Australian companies are denied the opportunity of safely investing in Chinese resources yet Chinese Government owned Companies operating in Australia continue to do their Governments bidding at the expense of Australian jobs and the Nations integrity.”
‪90% of all news articles about me whilst in parliament were fake news‬

The truth will set you free
The truth will set you free.

Statement from Waratah Coal and Clive Palmer

It is with great sorrow that we are now attempting to come to terms with the loss of Peter Lynch, who passed away in a tragic accident in Perth yesterday.

Peter was well known and respected in the mining community throughout Australia and South East Asia.

Peter studied at the University of New South Wales, graduating in 1988, with a degree in mining engineering. He made his mark early in life, being elected as University President in 1985 and later becoming a Board member and Chairman of the University of New South Wales Student Union.

Peter commenced his career as an open cut mining engineer in 1989 at German Creek Coal Mine, managed by Shell subsidiary Capricorn Coal Management Pty Ltd. He quickly advanced through the ranks and carved out a career in underground coal mining, becoming a senior mining engineer and undermanager at one of German Creek’s underground mines known as Central Colliery, where he worked until 1993.

Peter’s ingenuity, business savvy and entrepreneurial spirit allowed him to design, develop and manage a variety of large scale underground and open cut coal projects in the Bowen Basin between 1994 and 2005, notably Oaky North Underground and Moorvale Open Cut, where he held roles as General Manager and Managing Director.

In 2006, Peter joined the ranks of Waratah Coal Pty Ltd as Managing Director and provided Waratah with a vision to develop the Galilee Basin as a vertically integrated mine, rail and port project. His dedication to the Galilee Basin and Waratah allowed him to strike up strong enduring relationships with many State Owned Enterprises from China. 

His enormous enthusiasm for the business and the Galilee Basin, provided Waratah with the platform to launch what can only be described as a world class mineral resource and what will be one of Queensland’s greatest mine, rail and port infrastructure projects.

His zest for business flowed into his personal life, where his passions for restoring cars, boating and flying, were infectious. 

Our sincere condolences are expressed to Peter’s family and friends. He will be sadly missed by all who worked alongside him, especially by the Staff and Management here at Waratah Coal and the Mineralogy Group.
Peter Lynch had a great vision for  the galilee basin. His passing is a great loss to those who knew him and my deepest and most sincere condolences go to Peters family and friends

message:
Turnbull governments axes jobs Brisbane international airport

The Turnbull government has replaced Australian jobs with machines at Brisbane airport. Turnbull has eliminated hundreds of jobs by replacing Border Force  officers with machines,  effectively reducing security and services.

Turnbull has done this to promote the sale of automated equipment from overseas,  Clive Palmer stated in Brisbane today.
 
When I left Australia today there was four border force employees to deal with all traffic from Brisbane airport. The machines could not read my passport or the next passenger details either.

Australia will be the laughing stock of the western world if it persists with such a system. Tourism is now low on Turnbulls agenda. Even the copy cat name of border force is joke to all Australians and an insult to our National identity. We don't need to copy the US in creating aggressive forces that seek to persecute further than serve the Australian community.

Turnbull is a failure his government actions in axing Australian jobs for imported machines a disgrace.

If you’re travelling during the day overseas, I suggest a person should arrive 2 hours early and expect delays while poor Australian public servants dressed up in blue uniforms with gold braid struggle with Technology they don't understand that doesn't work.

After all Malcom was as Tony Abbott said, “Mr Technology”

Im convinced that Mayor Tom Tate and the council have told the truth.

Im also convinced they have been unknowingly misled by council officers who have discharged high powered rifles in residential areas for their own criminal purposes.

My staff and other witnesses will co-operate with the council and support Tom Tate's leadership to ensure the safety of all the residents of the Gold Coast.

Gold Coast City Council Gold Coast Bulletin 7 News Gold Coast 9 News Gold Coast

Gold Coast Council Officers armed with high powered rifles entered my property and fired shots killing my livestock and endangering human life.

Consultants and my employees observed them. They removed the carcasses of at least ten red deer from inside my property boundary and investigations have revealed they sold the meat from those animals to Gold Coast restaurants at up to $40 per kilogram.

The potentially murderous actions of those officers needs to be investigated and stopped. Tom Tate, the Mayor of the Gold Coast needs to take immediate executive action.

Small children under 10 years of age reside on my property and could have been killed by this raid.

Regardless of peoples political views, the use of weapons and discharging of firearms inside a person’s property is a criminal offence. I intend proceeding actions through the courts against the Gold Coast Council and their rogue killers and any cover up. I also intend to report this matter to police who have the duty to protect the residents of Queensland.

If guns are used to intimidate my staff and no action is taken to stop this, I will return to the political arena to change the Gold Coast Council for the benefit of all Gold Coast residents.

Small children and families should be able to play in their backyard without fear the Government will fire guns in or on their property.

Clive Palmer

Mayor Tom Tate Gold Coast City Council Gold Coast Bulletin 
#Guns, #Trespassing, #KillingAnimals #Endangeringlife

Clive Palmer sets goal shedding kilos 

Clive Palmer confirmed in Brisbane today that his weight loss since April this year has been 49kg and that he was on track to break through the 100kg barrier in the next few months.

“I hope my efforts will set an example for others to follow that things that seem unachievable at one time in life can be achieved with a strong discipline and commitment,’’ he said.

"I've used the same strong discipline and commitment that I used when I was in the Federal Parliament and applied it to bettering my own health.

“As a wise man once said, ‘some people look at things and say why, I look at things and say why not’.

“I need all the support I can get to break through the 100kg barrier.

“It has been hard and has required great constraint. I believe I can get there.

“God bless Australia and all its people,’’ he said.
I've now lost 49kg and at 104kg. Please support me to get through the 100kg barrier.

Media statement:

Clive Palmer Returns to Canberra

Clive Palmer returns to Canberra today (Wednesday, November 9) where tomorrow (Thursday,

November 10) he will again challenge and seek to change Australia’s laws.

The former Member of the House of Representatives and one time holder of the balance of power in

the Australian Parliament will challenge in the High Court of Australia the validity of Federal

Government laws. The laws that are being challenged require Australians who have not been

charged with an offence to appear before a court and to be forced to answer questions.

“I am defending and protecting the rights of all Australians who should not be treated contrary to

rules of natural justice by a government system that does not care about the rights of individual

Australians,’’ Mr Palmer said in Canberra.

The High Court of Australia will hear the matter on the morning of November 10. The Australian

Government, the Queensland Government, the Victorian Government and the Government of South

Australia have all intervened trying to stop Mr Palmer setting aside laws which deny Australians

basic liberties.

The High Court of Australia has scheduled a full hearing before seven judges of the High Court and

six legal teams representing the various governments and parties opposed to Clive Palmer’s

challenge.

Andrew Cook, Mr Palmer’s media representative stated: ‘”What is interesting is that the media has

not reported on this serious challenge to the system in Australia where Australian citizens can be

forced to attend and answer questions by governments against their will and interests.

“It’s a case of the government becoming all-powerful to crush the individual. Mr Palmer believes it’s

an abuse of the courts of Australia to be used to interrogate people and then following the

interrogation to sit and decide matters affecting their liberty.

“It takes some one of Clive Palmer’s courage to come forward and seek to stop injustice,’’ Mr Crook

said.

Mr Palmer says he was attacked by both sides of politics when his nickel refinery closed before the

last election. Yet despite major investigations by government directed by the Treasurer and the

Prime Minister nothing of any substance has emerged against him.

“That’s politics in Australia. Both sides work together and lie to the Australian people. I know what

Australians think of their Members of Parliament. Everyone knows Members of Parliament are only

in it for themselves,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“We need an Australia where public service is the highest calling. Where people are not personally

attacked because their views are different to others.

“We need a united country with a common purpose to do what is best for Australians. There are

millions of Australians serving this country. It not just about who is in parliament. The fact that the

High Court is hearing me tomorrow is a healthy sign for justice in this country. All Australians have

the right to be heard.

“If my challenge in the High Court of Australia is successful it will be the first step in changing

Australian laws where no Australian should be examined in court unless they have done something

wrong and been charged with an offence, and they know what the case is they have to answer.

“It makes you feel ashamed to live in a country where democracy is just a game.” Mr Palmer said.

ENDS

Returning to Canberra today to get justice for you in the High Court.
#auspol

The reports in the media today are disappointing and confirm the ongoing campaign against me and my commercial interests by my former political opponents because of my public service.

The leader of the Palmer United Party, Clive Palmer, has spoken out against the Prime Minister for comments he made against Tony Jones on the ABC’s Q&A program last night.

"Turnbull's attack last night was an attack on the independence and integrity of the ABC and an attempt to bully Tony Jones,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“Tony Jones remains as one of Australia's truly independent journalists. All Australians must defend and protect freedom of speech especially when it comes under attack by the leader of the Government,’’ Mr Palmer said.

ENDS

Clive Palmer confirmed in Brisbane today that he had not sought endorsement from the Palmer United Party to stand in the Queensland Senate election.

“Only Palmer United can keep the bastards honest,” he said.

Palmer to sue John Park and FTI for $1.2 billion

Clive Palmer announced in Brisbane today that he and two of his companies would serve a statement of claim in coming weeks seeking $1.2 billion in damages from John Park, his colleagues and FTI in respect of their administration of Queensland Nickel and the illegal diversion of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Funds and assets. 

Causes of action will include aiding and abetting a breach of trust and causing serious breaches of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement by Queensland Nickel.

"Park has opposed the appointment of a special purpose liquidator by the Commonwealth to cover up his wrong doing and has sought to convince the creditors’ committee of Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd (QN) to oppose it,” Mr Palmer said.

“John Park has done this for one purpose only and that is to hide his criminal actions and diversion of joint venture funding from a new liquidator. 

“In short, Park lied in his report as administrator to creditors including the Commonwealth." 

Mr Palmer said the special purpose liquidator should commence proceedings against Mr Park to recover the worker entitlements caused by his closing down of the refinery and sacking the workforce in breach of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement.

He said the refinery would still be operating if Mr Park hadn't sacked everyone.

"It was John Park who caused an unlawful breach of trust and contract disregarding the lawful rights of joint ventures to close the refinery and dismiss the workforce causing social upheaval to fill his own pockets,’’ Mr Palmer said.

"Park knows that if he had acted in accordance with the law, the closure and dismissal of the workforce didn't have to happen. Park and FTI need to be brought to account for their actions.

"ASIC has previously stated it was concerned that John Park and FTI were not putting the interests of unit holders before their own.

“I note the findings of the Honourable Justice Jean Dalton of the Queensland Supreme Court who stated when referring to Mr Park in relation to the LM funds case:  ‘The administrators of (LM) have in my view, demonstrated a preparedness to act in a way inconsistent with those owing a duty as a responsible entity and trustee under the Corporations Act. My view is that they have preferred their own commercial interests to the interest of the fund’,’’ he said.

"Park is at it again. He should have lost his licence following the LM scandal and been removed by the Supreme Court of Queensland as administrator but ASIC failed to act. If they had, thousands of jobs in North Queensland would have been preserved.

"The role of an administrator should be to do everything possible to preserve, protect and defend a business and to keep it operating, not to destroy it as Park has done.

“Park has, like the Supreme Court found in the LM case, preferred his own interests over the lives of so many families in Townsville,’’ Mr Palmer said.

"John Park and FTI have a serious conflict of interest. He should resign as liquidator of Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd in favour of the Commonwealth Government nominated liquidator. 

“Park cannot continue to draw millions of dollars in fees while he personally faces serious claims in the Supreme Court of Queensland from the Joint Venture parties over his disgraceful conduct as administrator of Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd,’’ Mr Palmer said.

ENDS:
Congratulations Suellen Wrightson. You will make a great Senator.

I can now understand why he doesn't want inquiry into the banks.

I will be having further discussions today with Senator Wang to see what we might do to bring the Prime Minister to account.

Being Prime Minister is not just a social job. Turnbull as a director of a company involved in any activity is required to know he can't escape criminal liability by saying he doesn't know.

message:
Palmer Correct Over Liberal Party Funding

Former life member and party spokesperson for the LNP, Clive Palmer, said the Arthur Sinodinos funding scandal showed he made the right choice in resigning from the Liberals before the last Federal Election.

“As a life member I resigned because of the party’s poor corporate governance and arrogant disregard for accountability,” the Federal leader of the Palmer United Party and Member for Fairfax said.

As the largest Liberal Party donor at the time, Mr Palmer confirmed he had spoken to the former Liberal Party Treasurer Michael Yabsley about seeing the party’s accounts.

Mr Palmer said he was concerned that funds weren’t being used appropriately.

“I was worried about the possibility of party funds being siphoned off for non-proper purposes. This was of grave concern to me,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“The Liberal Party is a party of lobbyists, with only 43% of donations it receives being declared to the Electoral Commission.

“The Palmer United Party declares 100% of all donations, something that every party needs to do for the sake of democracy.

“When donations are not fully declared, serious questions must be raised into the awarding of contracts worth billions of dollars, that’s why complete transparency is needed.

“The Federal Cabinet Secretary Arthur Sinodinos has refused to appear before a Senate Committee investigating political donations.

“His refusal to front a parliamentary inquiry into political donations despite the Senate directing him to is very questionable.

“These serious issues need to be investigated by the Federal Police,’’ Mr Palmer said.

ENDS

Have a read of this article from Crikey
http://www.crikey.com.au/2016/04/13/mayne-behind-the-australians-war-on-clive/

Media release

Clive Palmer blasts submarine decision

Federal leader of the Palmer United Party and Member for Fairfax, Clive Palmer, said today the Federal Government had made a poor decision in awarding the $50 billion Australian submarine contract to French shipbuilder DCNS.

“This is a terrible decision which was only made to help win votes for the Liberal Party and Christopher Pyne in South Australia,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“The French have never undertaken a submarine project of this size before.

“Australian defence is too important; one must ask questions about the timing of this announcement.

“This decision is nothing short of disgraceful and clearly shows the Australian Government is putting votes ahead of national security.

“It is a shocking example of pork barrelling,’’ Mr Palmer said.

ENDS

message:
Media release 

Stronger Communities Programme Funding Secured for Men’s Shed Nambour: Clive Palmer MP

Federal leader of the Palmer United Party and Member for Fairfax Clive Palmer MP congratulates the Nambour Men’s Shed on securing funding from the Stronger Communities Programme. 

Mr Palmer said that since its establishment in 2007 the Australian Men’s Shed Association has been playing an integral part in our communities.  It provides a safe haven where men can find social support and companionship with one another.

“It is extremely encouraging to see the money being allocated to such a worthy organisation,” he said.

The grant will enable the Nambour Men’s shed to build three pergolas which will be a community space where members can gather to share comradery over a cup of coffee and food while fixing the world’s problems.

On behalf of the Nambour Men’s Shed, Ian Ellis the President said, “we would like to thank the local member for Fairfax and the Commonwealth Government for making this grant available.”
“It is always difficult for a Men’s Shed to raise money, particularly for infrastructure projects. We are extremely pleased to be supported in this way.”

Mr Palmer said, “what is most uplifting about this project is the use of recycled material from a local demolition yard here in Nambour.’

“In this day and age, a strong focus on recycling must be a priority for all, individually and collectively, to ensure our world a better future,” Mr Palmer said. 

ENDS

Steven Miles claims about the Yabulu Refinery are misleading & incorrect. I met with the Environment department on site & they were satisfied with the tailings dam.

We have people onsite who are working on care & maintenance to ensure its environmentally compliant.

The proposed environmental clean-up laws are politically motivated and an example of the government arbitrarily singling out individuals.

We have heard from the Queensland Resource Council & Queensland Law Society who have concerns over the legislation that has been rushed through in an attempt to continue to politically attack me and our party.

People who are land holders, farmers who might have objected to the operation starting could be liable. It goes further including employees, or mum & dad investors, or large investors including the banks.

Will this see the end of investment in Queensland full stop?

Its the same sort of legislation that was akin in Nazi Germany in the 1930's and many Australians fought against these ideals & principles for a better Australia.

We need to raise the living standard of Australians, not seek to destroy all we stand for with legislation that is politically motivated and rushed for an improper purpose.

message:
Here is the audio of my speech that I delivered at Parliament House yesterday, clarifying the allegations that were made against me and my companies. 

My political opponents continue to attack me based on unfounded allegations in an attempt to keep out competition in parliament.

https://soundcloud.com/clive-palmer-981138912/clive-palmer-press-conference-qni-parliament-house-19-april-2016

Here is the text of my speech that I gave in Parliament House yesterday to clarify the misrepresentation that has been published in the media and used by my political opponents to try and destroy the reputation of me and the Palmer United Party.

A full audio will be uploaded in a separate post.

This address is given today because the Leader of the House, Christopher Pyne, would not consent to me making a statement in respect of Queensland Nickel. I thought considering the misinformation that the government had distributed, I need to set the record straight.

Just before the 18th of January 2016, Clive Mensink, the managing director of Queensland Nickel made 232 people redundant from Queensland Nickel. Mr Mensink ensured that when they left the refinery they had been paid two weeks wages in advance. He then appointed the Administrator and directed that worker entitlements be immediately calculated. Once the entitlements were calculated they were given to the Administrator who decided not to pay them. The management of Queensland Nickel had no control over the company once they appointed the Administrator. On the 18th of January 2016, in an effort to save the continued operation of the plant, the management of Queensland Nickel placed Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd into administration.

The administration and operation continued until Mr Mensink was advised by John Park around the 1st of March 2016 that unless he received $10 million dollars that week he was going to close the refinery down. He made the same demand to the Queensland Government.

I did not want that to happen and had lost confidence in the Administrator to keep the refinery running.

On the 3rd of March 2016, the joint venture partners, QNI Resources Pty Ltd and QNI Metals Pty Ltd, 100% privately owned companies of mine, resolved to appoint a new company that was not in administration as manager of the joint venture.

I personally put up some of my private assets to secure a $23million line of credit I planned to make available to the new manager.

Under the Queensland Joint Venture Agreement, the old manager, Queensland Nickel, on the appointment of the new manager was required to transfer the joint venture bank account together with the other assets and general approvals that Queensland Nickel had to give to the new manager. 

The millions of dollars in the joint venture bank account and debtors when added to the 23 million dollars I had arranged through my own personal efforts would have allowed the business to continue and employ over 550 people. 

John Park decided he would not transfer the bank account of the joint venture to the new manager of the joint venture as he was legally required to do. 

In so doing, John Park preferred his personal fees over the rights of the 550 people to continue to be employed.  Instead of doing a handover John Park closed the refinery making 550 people redundant and John Park decided not to pay their entitlements. 

No one in any company I am involved in made that decision. John Park for two months worked as Administrator and charged $4.5 million dollars. 

John Park then produced a report which raised a number of serious issues in relation to me personally and my companies.

In his report he was seeking a further payment of $5 million dollars to act as a liquidator of Queensland Nickel. He requested these funds from the Liberal National Government. 

His main criticisms on me were that:
(1)  I acted as a shadow director of Queensland Nickel. 
(2)  That I and my company had siphoned money out of Queensland Nickel.
(3)  That Queensland Nickel was insolvent of 27th of November 2015 because of a demand that Queensland Nickel had received from Arizon.

Firstly, Mr Park stated that I had acted as a shadow director of Queensland Nickel.

Queensland Nickel was manager of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture and was required under the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement to follow the direction of the joint venture committee of which I was the Chairman.

The agreement was drawn up in 1992 when the Queensland Government was a major shareholder of the joint venture.

Under the terms of the Joint Venture Agreement, Queensland Nickel was prohibited from owning any property or engaging in any other activity other than as manager of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture.
All directions I gave Queensland Nickel have been in accordance with my role as Chairman of the joint venture committee which Queensland Nickel is contractually required to follow such directions related solely to the Joint Venture property.

This is well documented and was ignored by John Park. Through the time of his appointment, Mr Park never made such allegations to me because he knew they were false. Nor did Mr Park give me the opportunity to respond to them which natural justice requires.

This matter is of no concern to me whatsoever but has been used by my political opponents to try to destroy me and my party.
The report is an attempt to get the Federal Government to pay him $5 million to liquidate of Queensland Nickel.

In early December 2015, my company Mineralogy made application in the West Australian Supreme Court to get a payment of $60 million from the Chinese state-owned company Sino Iron owed to Mineralogy so the funds could be invested in Queensland Nickel. All that is on the court record.

The allegation that I or any of my companies have ever been the recipients of any funds from Queensland Nickel is just not true. The consolidated accounts of the joint venture companies, audited by EY clearly demonstrated that John Park made misleading and deceptive comments about this matter in his report.

Any payments that were made in 2013 to Palmer United Party were the funds beneficially owned by companies 100% privately owned or controlled by me who had no employees whatsoever.

The allegations made by Mr Park are completely false as all allegations made against me by the political parties I have endured over the last three years since I was elected to the House of Representatives. 

While Mr Park stated words to the effect that Queensland Nickel was insolvent because of a demand from Aurizon on the 27th of November 2015. He neglects to state that Aurizon agreed in writing to extend the date for this payment to be made to the 18th of January 2016.

There is no substance or finding in Mr Park’s report.

Consequently, the joint venture parties have commenced action in the Supreme Court of Queensland against the Administrators seeking appropriate orders and declarations.

We have commissioned PwC to complete and issue an independent report on the Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd solvency up until the appointment of the Administrator. We will release such report at the end of May 2016.

There have been over 22,000 workers made redundant in Queensland. The Commonwealth and State Government have done nothing to deal with this issue.

I met with the Prime Minister at his office in Sydney on the 9th of October 2015. I had had a series of discussions with the member for Herbert, Ewen Jones during the last quarter of 2015. Subsequently, I stated that falling world nickel prices and the consequences temporary closure of the nickel refinery in Townsville would have for the employment for 2,500 people. I told Ewen Jones the refinery paid $70 million a year in tax to the Commonwealth and $12.5 million to Queensland. With around $600 million in exports, it underpinned North Queensland’s economy, the refinery needed $20 million dollars to keep operating.  The member for Herbert was hopeless. His response was just leave it to the Prime Minister. The PM said because I was a member of parliament, it was not something the government would consider. When BHP decided to close the refinery in 2009 the nickel price was $7.50 a pound, in late 2015 it fell to $3.50. 

From 2009 to 2015 my companies have spent over 4 billion dollars keeping 2,500 people employed for seven years. Production costs dropped by 50%. Everywhere lies and falsehoods have been canvassed in the press and by government ministers and the media. There have been no findings against me by any court or any party, just speculation. If something which isn’t true was, matters which have no relevance to true facts.

No funds owned by Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd have ever been paid to me or any of my companies.  No person working for any companies of mine have ever dismissed workers and decided not to pay entitlements.   Manipulated commodity prices have destroyed our country.   China gives 30 billion yuan to their metals processing industry, the Canadian government gives free electricity to their resources industry, how can Australian industry compete? 
22,000 jobs lost in Queensland and a hundred thousand across Australia. We need action to save 14,000 jobs at Whyalla now. 

The Chinese steel industry is dumping its steel stock at less than it costs on the world market, to bring down the price of steel and eliminate competition, jobs and steel production in Australia, and the Australian Government does nothing but boast about a one-way trade agreement.

The media attention on Queensland Nickel allows the government to escape responsibility for doing nothing while Australian manufacturing industry is destroyed.

The Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry are just hopeless, they sit on their hands while Australians lose their jobs. The Government won’t even allow me a 15 minutes spot in this parliament to make a full explanation or deal with matters of national interest.

In 1970, the Queensland Government had provided a $43 million guarantee for Queensland Nickel. The Queensland Government and later BHP Billiton had been shareholders of Queensland Nickel when over 80% of worker entitlements had accrued but they had failed to provide for them.

It was Anna Bligh, the Queensland Labor Premier, that discussed with me purchasing Queensland Nickel and the joint venture in 2009 when BHP decided to close it. In 2009 the price of nickel was $7.50 per pound. It was around $3.50 per pound when the Administrator was appointed.

The nickel price crashed in October 2015. The consolidated group had net assets of $1.95 billion dollars. Mr Mensink determined he should seek a bank overdraft of 20-30million dollars.

He with the Financial Controller and myself, visited six banks who all stated they were not prepared to lend to resource companies in Queensland.

As the Queensland Government had originally set up the refinery with a $43 million guarantee for 2 years in 1970’s and had been a major shareholder in 1992, setting up the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement and Queensland Labor Premier Anna Bligh had secured my investment in the business in 2009. We informed the Queensland Government of the situation.

On the 30th of September 2015, meetings were held with the Queensland Government.  Meetings continued to be held up until late October seeking support to keep the refinery open.  This was because the banks funding was not available with the key banks and confirming that banks were not lending.

In September 2015, the auditor EY signed the joint venture accounts stating 1.95 billion dollars in net assets. At the beginning of October, the forecast for the coming year showed a surplus of over $60 million was expected.

Malcolm Turnbull
When Malcolm Turnbull decided to challenge Tony Abbott for the Prime Ministership, he said he did it to bring about economic change.  Since then he has done nothing for our economy. Right across this country, companies are placed in liquidation, plants close and jobs are lost. The Australian Government needs to act.

Scott Morrison
He said that he would lean on ASIC to take action against me.  His comments are similar to Hitler when Himlar used the Gestapo in Germany. Independent government officers of the Commonwealth should be free from ministerial prejudice, interference and allow the rule of law to prevail in this country not political direction.

Senator Cash and Ewen Jones performance on this issue is disgraceful. It was Ewen Jones who failed to stick up for Townsville in November and December 2015, knowing full well the consequences of him failing to act for the people of Townsville. To now speak to the public about the suffering of families is disgraceful but typical of politicians in this place.  

For Senator Cash to say last week that this is the first time the Federal Government had to help is just a lie, even the media reports confirm the Queensland Premier discussed this with the Prime Minister late last year.  Again this is just political.

The fact of the matter is that I arranged for 12 billion dollars to be spent in this country in developing my iron ore leases in Western Australia.  These projects created around 60,000 jobs during construction.
Since 2009 we have spent over $4 billion dollars in keeping 2,500 people employed in Townsville for seven years. What have Turnbull, Cash and Morrison ever done? What jobs have they even established or created? It’s easy for them to criticise people who have created new jobs.

Australians need to understand that ongoing negative attitudes will mean the country will see that no one will ever invest in major projects again.  

It is better to invest in heavy industry in Canada, South Africa and China.  The Government needs to lifts its game and take action now to save the 14,000 jobs threatened in Whyalla.

There is a large team at the refinery in North Queensland attending to care and maintenance and ensuring compliance with environmental conditions.

The joint venture intends to reopen the refinery later in the year and create up to 1000 jobs in Townsville.

Media release:
 
Morrison abusing Ministerial power to lobby ASIC: Clive Palmer
 
Treasurer Scott Morrison was abusing his power as a Minister to lobby ASIC and make personal attacks over Queensland Nickel, the Federal leader of the Palmer United Party and Member for Fairfax, Clive Palmer, said today.
 
Mr Palmer said politicians from both major parties were engaging in a witch hunt against him to protect the two-party system rather than acknowledging the real reason for Queensland Nickel’s difficulties which was falling global commodity prices.
 
He said in the last 24 hours Mr Morrison, Michaela Cash, Bill Shorten, Brendan O’Connor and Ewen Jones had all attacked him personally over Queensland Nickel rather than deal with the facts.
 
“In just one example in the media today we see Scott Morrison abusing his power as a minister to lobby ASIC.  This is a blatant case of Mr Morrison using his office for an improper purpose to attack me personally for political reasons,’’ he said.
 
“He is attacking me when in fact he is hiding the short comings of his Federal Government in assisting the people of North Queensland.”
 
Mr Palmer said the Federal Member for Herbert, Ewen Jones, did not have any success lobbying his own government for assistance for the Townsville community.
 
“If assistance was provided we wouldn’t have seen job losses,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
“The real story why Queensland Nickel is in receivership is because of the low commodity prices.
 
“The Chinese and Canadian Governments have helped resource sectors in their countries, so we aren’t on a level playing field.
 
“The Australian Government continues to be reactive instead of proactive, while job losses continue to mount up across the resources sector.
 
“We have seen 23,000 job losses in the resource sector in Queensland in the last 12 months and, most recently, the situation unfolding at Whyalla.
 
“This is a political witch hunt against me by politicians who want to keep the two-party system intact and reject any independent views,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
ENDS:
Senator Zhenya Wang

http://www.afr.com/business/mining/quarter-of-nickel-miners-seen-battling-to-survive-in-price-rout-20160413-go5103

Palmer Releases Truth on Queensland Nickel
Federal leader of the Palmer United Party and Member for Fairfax Clive Palmer has released the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement to clear up inaccuracies in the Administrators Report issued yesterday by FTI Consulting.
 
“This document will validate the structure of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement but in short the report released yesterday is nothing more than a beat up,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
“Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd (QN) was the General Manager and Manager of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture.
 
“As a manager, until March 3, 2016, QN had contractually agreed under Clause 4.1 of the Joint Venture Agreement to follow the direction of the Joint Venture Owners Committee in carrying out the Joint Venture.
 
“The Joint Venture Owners Committee operates through its members to carry out the function of the Joint Venture Owners Committee in accordance with Clause 4.1 of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement.”
 
Clause 4.1 states as follows:
 
4. JOINT VENTURE OWNERS COMMITTEE
 
4.1 Establishment and Powers of Committee
 
The responsibility and authority for the conduct of the Joint Venture will be vested in a committee (hereinafter referred to as the “Joint Venture Owners Committee” or the “JVOC”), the purposes of which shall be to consider and determine general policy and strategic matters for the Joint Venture and to establish policies which shall achieve the aims and objectives of the Joint Venture. In particular, without limiting the foregoing, the JVOC will be required:
 
(a)        to provide the Managers with directions in respect of the duties and responsibilities of the Managers and to monitor the performance of those duties and responsibilities in accordance with directions given;
 
(b)        to establish and monitor the achieving of production and cost targets by the General Manager;
 
(c)        to initiate consideration of proposed capital expenditures and Development Programmes;
 
(d)        to review performance and financial reports furnished to it pursuant to Clause 5.3, as applicable;
 
(e)        to cause to be prepared and/or maintained one or more manuals (“Project Manuals”) in such form as it shall determine for the purpose of governing arrangements and procedures relating to the operation of the Joint Venture, which arrangements and procedures shall include:
 
(i)         the personnel to be employed or retained by the Managers on behalf of the Joint Venture including the assignment of authority and responsibility to such personnel and the procedures for their hiring and discharge;
 
(ii)        the entering into of contracts relating to the operation of the Joint Venture including the delegation of authority to the Managers or to one or both Joint Venturers to approve actions proposed to be taken pursuant to such contracts; and
 
(iii)       the submission and approval of the formant and content of financial reports, performance reports, annual financial plans, Development Programmes, budgets for capital expenditure and budgets for Development Capital Expenditures for Development Programmes referred to hereinafter;
 
(f)        to review and approve, with or without amendment, proposed financial plans for the operation of the Joint Venture submitted to it pursuant to Clause 6.2;
 
(g)        to review and approve, with or without amendment, proposed Development Programmes initiated by it or submitted to it by any Joint Venturer or by a Manager as provided in Clause 5.3; and
 
(h)        to review and approve, with or without amendment, proposed budgets for Development Capital Expenditures and proposed revisions to Approved Development Budgets and provided in Clause 6.3.
 
 
Mr Palmer said the Joint Venture Agreement was signed in 1992.
 
“At no time did I need to be a director of QN to ensure that operations were carried out in accordance with the directions of the Joint Venture Owners Committee.
 
“Any activity that I have been involved in since 2012 was as a member of the Joint Venture Owners Committee carrying out its functions,’’ he said.
 
Clause 4.1 (a) states in detail the Joint Venture Owners Committee will be required “to provide the Managers with directions in respect of the duties and responsibilities of the Managers and to monitor the performance of those duties and responsibilities in accordance with directions given.”
 
The General Manager’s role is set out in Clause 5.2 of the Joint Venture Agreement and the General Manager (QN) role is set out in the Joint Venture Agreement as being “subject to the direction of the Joint Venture Owner Committee”. 
 
“QN was contractually bound to follow the Joint Venture Owners Committee in respect of Joint Venture business.
 
“QN is not and has never been a Joint Venturer. At no time was I a shadow director of QN,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
“The accounts of my two private companies, QNI Metals Pty Ltd and QNI Resources Pty Ltd have been lodged with ASIC for the past six years and contain all transactions referred to in the Administrators Report.
 
“QN is prohibited by Clause 5.5(b) of the Joint Venture Agreement to carry out any other role other than Manager while it is Manager.
 
“The allegations contained in the Administrators Report do not related to QN activity. QN has never had any beneficial ownership in the assets of my private companies including cash at bank.
 
“For the avoidance of doubt, I attach a full copy of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture Agreement. FTI and Administrators are not administrators or liquidators of any of the Joint Venture Parties.
 
“In September 2015, the auditor of QN signed the 2013 accounts for QN Group confirming solvency. The Administrator say because of a default notice by Aurizon, QN could be insolvent
 
“On page 44 of the Administrators Report, they say ‘The critical event which has driven the determination of the date of insolvency is the date Aurizon withdrew from the negotiated arrangements and issued a demand for payment of the total debt of $11.9M, being 27 November 2015’.
 
“What the Administrators do not say is that Aurizon agreed in writing to extend the time for compliance to 18th January 2016 so that a financing solution could be achieved.
 
“On 18th January 2016 when said solution was not achieved, the director then complied with his obligations and placed QN in administration. There was no insolvent trading,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
ENDS:

Media release:
 
Administrators’ report filled with untrue statements: Clive Palmer
 
Clive Palmer said today that the report released by the administrators of Queensland Nickel (QNI) contained a number of derogatory and untrue statements in relation to himself, QNI and others.
 
“The truth of the matter is the administrators are embarking on a campaign to secure more funds for their exorbitant fees,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
“They have already paid themselves $4 million and are seeking to liquidate Queensland Nickel to pay themselves another $5 million.”
 
Mr Palmer said at no time in his dealings with administrators FTI Consulting did they raise any of the allegations now being made.
 
“The administrators did so without providing myself or others named in their report the opportunity to be aware of such allegations or discuss such matters.
 
“The report calls into question the professionalism and impartiality of FTI. Their findings are filled with innuendo.”
 
Mr Palmer said the public had a right to know the truth.
 
“Queensland Nickel employees who were first made redundant were paid two weeks wages in advance while their redundancy and entitlements were being determined.
 
“It was FTI who made the decision not to pay entitlements, not any person working for Queensland Nickel.
 
“FTI continued to trade the company for over a month with Joint Venture funds without the Joint Venture’s approval,” Mr Palmer said.
 
“On March 3, Queensland Nickel ceased to be the manager of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture.
 
“The administrator refused to transfer the joint venture bank account to the new manager as required by the joint venture agreement,’’ he said.
 
Mr Palmer said he obtained a $23 million line of credit which when added to the joint venture bank account would have kept the refinery open avoiding further redundancies.

“Instead the administrator decided to sack all 550 employees, not pay their entitlements and to close the refinery.

“I want to be clear that at no time did I act as a shadow director,” he said.
 
Mr Palmer will later today release documents showing the role in which he acted, proving the allegations are false.
 
ENDS

"For three years, I have come on your program, heard allegations about this and that, taking $12,000,000 its just rubbish"

Media statement
 
Four Corners Needs to Give Clive Palmer a Fair Go
 
Clive Palmer has offered to appear on Four Corners live to answer allegations being raised by the program.
 
The program contains a number of factual errors and if broadcast will cause substantial damage to Mr Palmer.  Four Corners needs to be corrected.
 
In relation to Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd, the facts are that Queensland Nickel has never given loans to Mr Palmer or his companies.  Any reports to the contrary are false and have been written to cause malicious damage.
 
Queensland Nickel employees who were first made redundant were paid two weeks wages in advance while their redundancy and entitlements were being determined.
 
The administrator made the decision not to pay entitlements, not Mr Palmer or any person working for Queensland Nickel. The administrator continued to trade the company for over a month following that decision with Queensland Nickel funds.
 
On March 3, Queensland Nickel ceased to be the manager of the Queensland Nickel Joint Venture. The administrator refused to transfer the joint venture bank account to the new manager as required by the joint venture agreement.
 
Mr Palmer had obtained a $23 million line credit which when added to the joint venture bank account would have kept the refinery open avoiding further redundancies. Instead the administrator decided to sack all employees and close the refinery. If those people had kept their jobs they would not been eligible for entitlements.

The accrual of entitlements mostly took place under Queensland Government and BHP ownership, which they failed to provide. Any suggestion that Mr Palmer has or could have any liability is false and any serious suggestion that he for whatever reason has done anything but act honourably is untrue.
 
As is normal process, there is a report being released to creditors in the coming week by the administrators.
 
For the ABC to broadcast prior to the release of such a report is clearly designed to cause serious damage to Mr Palmer for an improper purpose. Why does the ABC choose to broadcast before and not after the release of the report?
 
Mr Palmer has offered Four Corners a live interview.  Four Corners refused to allow Mr Palmer to appear on the program when it is broadcast to answer any allegation.
 
Such refusal merely confirms Four Corners’ lack of willingness to deal with the truth and its determination to run a biased broadcast not in accordance with its charter.
 
Mr Palmer, like any Australian, should be entitled to a fair go.
 
The real truth is that as world commodity prices have collapsed and more than 22,000 Queenslanders in the mining sector have lost their jobs, neither the State nor Federal Governments have had a credible response.
 
The Chinese Government has provided 30 billion yuan of assistance to its metal industry and the Canadian Government is waiving electricity costs for their mineral processors to save jobs. The legitimate question is how can Australian industry compete with that?
 
The absence of similar coverage of the shareholders of the operations at Whyalla or the companies of the 22,000 sacked Queensland workers raises the question of whether the ABC is running this story for political purposes.  Considering the closeness of the current election and the lack of coverage by the ABC of the Palmer United Party’s political achievements, there appears to be serious issue of bias.
 
Mr Palmer repeats his request for equal time being allocated on any broadcast for him to appear in person and provide answers to any allegation on any subject. The refusal by the ABC to allow Mr Palmer to appear is unbalanced and a denial of the public’s right to know.
 

ENDS

Media release:
 
Pyne must answer for Whyalla job losses: Clive Palmer
 
Federal leader of the Palmer United Party and Member for Fairfax Clive Palmer said recent job losses at the Whyalla steelworks had highlighted the Federal Government’s shocking lack of support for Australian industry.
 
“Federal Industry Minister Christopher Pyne has much to answer for over the 2000 jobs lost in Whyalla with Arrium going into voluntary administration,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
“As job losses continue to mount up in the resources sector around Australia, the Liberal Government has been useless in shaping policy that reflects the current global downturn in commodity prices.
 
“The Chinese Government is spending $30bn to support mineral processing whilst the Canadian Government is waiving electricity costs for their mineral processors to save jobs and Malcolm Turnbull and Christopher Pyne stand by and watch Australian industry destroyed.
 
“Members of government should realise they are elected to do something and support Australian industry.
 
“We need a national policy for the resources industry given the global downturn. At present Australians are being played for mugs,’’ Mr Palmer said.
 
“22,000 jobs have been lost in the resources sector in Queensland and there has been no response from The Fixer, only criticism for those who want to keep industry going in Australia.”
 
Mr Palmer said it was hypocritical that Mr Pyne had received support from his government to help Whyalla steelworkers while nothing was being done to assist Queensland Nickel workers in Townsville.
 
“The Federal Member for Herbert, Ewen Jones, has failed to get the support of the Turnbull Government to help QNI and has let the people of Townsville down. The people of North Queensland should vote him out at the next election for failing them,” Mr Palmer said.
 
“What is good for Whyalla should be good for Townsville.
 
“Christopher Pyne seems to get all the support he needs. Is it because the Liberals are worried about him losing his seat to Nick Xenophon’s party?
 
“Mr Pyne and Mr Turnbull are playing political games with people’s lives,’’ Mr Palmer said.

message:
Austerity - What is it and how does it impact us?

In most macroeconomic models austerity measures generally increase unemployment as government spending falls, reducing jobs in the public and/or private sector. Meanwhile, tax increases reduce household disposable income, thus reducing spending and consumption.

Since government spending contributes to the Gross Domestic Product (GDP), reducing the spending may result in a higher debt-to-GDP ratio, a key measure of a country's debt burden.

When an economy is operating at near capacity, higher short-term deficit spending (stimulus) can cause interest rates to rise, resulting in a reduction in private investments, which in turn reduces economic growth. In the case of excess capacity, however, the stimulus may result in an increase in employment and output.[4][5]

We need to stimulate domestic demand, turbo charge our economy and increase the amount of cash that circulates to improve our standard of living which in turn will grow government revenue which can be invested in our health and education sectors.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austerity

You can view my interview on the Senate Voting Reforms introduced to parliament.

message:
Malcom Turnbull: More Bull than True

At both by-elections since Malcom Turnbull was elected Prime Minister, the government has experienced major swing against it. First in the seat of Canning, where the swing was 6.8 percent against the government, and then more recently in the seat of North Sydney, where the swing was 13 percent against the government.

Yet in the News Limited press and other media, Turnbull is supposed to have overwhelming support. It just doesn’t add up.

It’s a great time to be an Australian, Turnbull tells us, but it is hardly a great time for the 954,000 unemployed Australians and their families, or the millions on low income support or low income super.

Turnbull was clear from the start that he was there to implement Tony Abbott’s policy. Tony Abbott decided to hang around to contest the next election. If Turnbull decides to retire after next election and collect his investments in the Cayman Islands before moving to his apartment in New York to retire, Tony could be our next Prime Minister and implement the rest of his policy including the 2014 budget.

It is clear that the majority of the government, which includes the Nationals, support Abbott. Like all politicians, they first support their election.

Not a bad deal in your sixties to be given the Prime Ministership, even if only for 18 months, provided you don’t change policy, smile a lot and make announcements.

But it is still a cold winter in Tasmania, in the Latrobe Valley, in Elizabeth and in Redfern, in Western Queensland, and in the hearts of the men and women of Australia who have faith in our country and all it could be.

Clive Palmer

Malcolm Turnbull just seems to be following Abbott's policy. How would our Prime Minister like it if his grandchildren were locked up in detention?

I dont believe that any babies should be in detention and I find it hard to fathom that anyone could allow a baby to be sent back to a detention centre when we continually hear of the rape and the abuse suffered at the hands of those employed by our commonwealth. It is wrong and we shouldnt let it happen.

Malcolm Turnbull is responsible for the care and protection of children and its morally corrupt to send any of baby or child back to detention.

Please share this post if you agree that no child belongs in detention.

Personal attacks disappointing for Australia: Clive Palmer

Leader of the Palmer United Party, Clive Palmer, said today that the frenzied personal attacks on him were disappointing for Australia.

“These attacks commenced when I was elected to Parliament as the establishment, both the Labor and Liberal parties and their supporters, reacted to protect the two party system,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“There has been little discussion or attack at any policies of our party or what we achieved in Parliament. 

“Palmer United stopped the 2014 budget and saved this country from austerity,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“There is no truth or substance in the continuing false allegations and attacks against me. Personally I can understand how in the future Australians will not invest in their own country or seek to save jobs of other Australians considering the media coverage given to Queensland Nickel. 

“Queensland Nickel has kept the North Queensland economy going following the decision by BHP to close operations in 2009. 

“The Liberal and Labor parties are the same, they have no interest in democracy or doing what is best for Australians,’’ Mr Palmer said.

ENDS

message:
You can read this article in the Sunshine Coast Daily after my letter to the Prime Minister.

http://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/clive-defends-qld-nickels-record-in-letter-to-turn/2921217/

You can read the full letter that was sent to the Prime Minister today with regards to Queensland Nickel.

Dear Prime Minister

RE: Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd

Notwithstanding your or my comments in the press about the above matter, I am duty bound to write to you to make it absolutely clear so that you have the relevant facts of the matter.

In 2009, when BHP Billiton had decided to close the facility and devastate the North Queensland economy, the world nickel price was higher than US$7 per pound. Today, the world nickel price is US$3.80 per pound and the plant is still in operation, employing directly over 550 people and providing a further 1600 jobs from its activities to the people of Townsville.

In 2009, following discussion with the then labor Queensland Premier Anna Bligh, companies that I own agreed to inject tens of millions of dollars for the acquisition of Queensland Nickel and to operate it more efficiently and continue to impact the employment of thousands of people.

The productivity gained in the plant’s operations is the best achieved in any manufacturing facility in Australia, where the cost of production has halved in comparison to the cost of production under the former BHP management. The excellent work carried out by the management of Queensland Nickel has allowed over $4bn to be invested in North Queensland since 2009.

As you are aware, the management and workers of the plant can only concentrate on their cost base. As a 100% export plant, they are totally dependent upon the world commodity prices. During our meeting late last year in Sydney, I made you aware that the Nickel price had collapsed since October 2015.

The company’s auditors, Ernst & Young, signed an auditor’s report including solvency of the company in September 2015. At that time it was my understanding the company had projected a surplus of $73m for the year and, in the audited accounts, had a net asset base of $1.95bn and no substantial debt. It was reasonable to assume that a banking institution would have funded a small amount of debt on the balance sheet. For reasons best known to the Treasurer, they failed to do so.

In contrast to the Australian Government’s attitude in respect of our metals manufacturing industry, the Canadian Government has waived all charges for power and electricity for all their metals manufacturers due to the low commodity prices. The Chinese Government has provided CNY$30,000,000,000 directly to its metals manufacturing industry. It is disappointing that the Australian Government on this issue is more interested in taking cheap political shots against a management team that has worked so hard to achieve a positive outcome for the company and the country that the Australian Government has obfuscated its duty to ensure there is a level playing field for Australian manufacturers under the World Trade Organisation.

Other Issues

Whilst there have been other issues raised in the press, we have to remember that 22,000 jobs have been lost in Queensland in the resource industry because of declining resource prices, international manipulation of those prices and the failure of the government to even be alive to these issues. These are issues for which the Australian Government refuses to take any actions necessary to counterbalance the effect of these measures on our economy.

The media coverage of this matter has been politicised without addressing the real issues. From a policy perspective, there has been the redundancy of 237 workers in Townsville which has had the effect of preserving jobs for the 550 workers that are still employed directly by Queensland Nickel and jobs for the 1600 workers that depend upon the refinery operations in Townsville.

I have been informed that on the Thursday, when redundancies were carried out, each employee of Queensland Nickel was immediately paid two weeks wages in advance pending final calculation of their entitlements in accordance with the Fair Work Act.

During the period when calculating their entitlements, the director of the company, in accordance with obligations under corporation law, appointed an administrator to the company. That administrator then made the determination that workers’ entitlements would not be paid under the administrators and would be subject to a deed of arrangement. Neither the shareholders nor the management had any decision making powers over such matters and it is therefore very unreasonable for there to be any attack politically on the management of the company pending the outcome of the administrators’ report. There can be no doubt that in the years from 2009 onwards, when the company was subject to audit, that it met all solvency tests as certified by the company auditor.

There has been substantial comment by your ministers that raised the question whether a private family-owned company, which is certified as being fully solvent, has the right to donate funds to the political party of its choosing. As you should be aware, in the years prior to 2013, the political party which you lead, was the beneficiary of substantial donations from Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd. I have heard no such criticism in respect to those donations. Moreover, it is not reasonable or proper to make comments in respect of matters that are subject to any administrators’ report while that report is being compiled. 

As you are aware, as I have publicly stated at the time following my election to the federal parliament, I have retired from business. I am concerned with the decline of jobs in the country and the systematic failure of the Australian and State Governments to seriously address industrial policy in this country.

Yours faithfully,
Clive F Palmer
Federal Member for Fairfax

See the interview with Tony Jones on Lateline last night.

Here is my speech in the Federation Chamber today on Australia Day and the Citizenship ceremony that I presided over at Palmwoods.

Palmwoods is a great community and this is the second time I have been the presiding officer. A special thanks must go to Jenny McCarthy who organised the troops and made the whole event a success and to our MC Mike Burns who did a wonderful job.

Citizenship was not just for those present, but it would change the destiny of those future generations yet to be born. They committed future generations to our country and all that it stands for.

Seeing so many happy new citizens of Australia, reminded me how all of us, in this place and throughout the nation, have a responsibility to do all that we can do to make our new Australians welcome in our society.

https://youtu.be/pPKmF3zHoT0

See my speech on Equality in Australia and the reasons why I believe Parliament should lead on this issue.

Women have had the right to Vote for 114years, yet we still fail to have equality in the parliament and cabinet.

Men and Women think differently. They approach problems from different perspectives, and Australia deserves the benefit from wise council,  of all its people, not just some.

I believe there is a need for legislation to ensure we have at least a 40% representation of each gender in cabinet.

You can listen to my full speech below.

message:
Message from Clive Mensink, Managing Director Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd

When Clive Palmer’s companies acquired Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd (QN) in 2009, the price of Nickel was around $7 a pound. At the time I made the decision to make redundancies at Queensland Nickel the price had been as low as $3.50 a pound. In 2009 I estimate QN’s production cost was close to $8 a pound and seven years later it’s closer to $4 a pound. QN’s improvement and efficiency in productivity are the best in any industry in Australia during the period of ownership of Mr Palmer and that is a fact. 

In 2009 the Queensland Labor government wanted assistance in keeping QN’s operations going because of the significance to the North Queensland economy. In 2009, it was estimated that QN provide 2,400 jobs in the community. QN is the largest private employer in North Queensland and the largest user of the Townsville port. 

QN exports are between $600,000,000 and $700,000,000 each year and it provides approximately $1.4 billion dollars a year to the Townsville economy. QN workers’ pay approximately $50,000,000 each year in group tax and the company pays around $20,000,000 each year in GST. QN is responsible for payments of $12,500,000 a year to the Queensland Government.

The current structure under which QN operates was established in 1991 when the Queensland Government held more than 25% of the shares in QN and provided substantial guarantees to ore suppliers and other creditors. 

Since 2009 QN has invested over $4,000,000,000 in North Queensland’s economy by its operations and kept thousands of people employed each year, of which would have had no jobs over the last seven years if it was not for the actions of the new management of the company from 2009. 

While the press concentrates on issues which have no bearing on the operations or the decisions I took to place the company in administration, I thought this is a good time to set the record straight in respect of recent events.
 
(Refer to Graph from Picture 1)

Queensland 2015
In the last 12 months, around 22,000 jobs have been lost in the Queensland Resource sector primarily because of falling commodity prices. The media have failed to cover those tragedies and it’s disappointing how the media and politicians try to benefit from our company misfortune. It has been an extremely poor performance from government that there has been little to no real action to support the workers and the communities that have been devastated. 

Unfortunately, most of the companies have just closed down and closed operations permanently. The actions taken by QN needs to be seen in that light and it needs to be clearly understood by current and former workers and management of QN that what QN has done and what our strategy has been.
 
(Refer to graph from Picture 2 and 3)
 
The prime reason for QN administration and associated events is the price for Nickel, which is at its lowest for 15 years and as stated previously was around half of what it was when BHP wanted to close the plant. QN’s performance is more than twice as good as BHP’s management was when they had the plant the numbers prove it.
 
(Refer to graph from Picture 4)

During the weeks prior to the redundancies, the QN management team was working on plans to further improve our existing operations and identify how QN could keep the maximum number of people employed in this low Nickel price environment. Various options and cash flow models were considered and QN actively sought financial assistance, which was looking positive. 

I determined firstly on a cash flow basis there would have to be a reduction in workers and output to provide QN with a positive cash flow to continue. In this regard we had to make 237 employees redundant and when each of those employees was made redundant, they left their employment with two weeks’ wages which had already been paid in advance. I immediately took steps to have their entitlements calculated and I then had to consider the impact and likely impact on future creditors and other financial efforts. I formed the view that QN’s best chance of survival and restructure was for QN to go into administration.

Once the administrator was appointed he or she has the power to decide how entitlements will be dealt with, my powers as a Director are suspended during administration. When we consider that there is approximately 2,400 jobs in Townsville dependent on QN activities in one form or another, by reducing the QN workforce by 237 jobs and restructuring operations, QN has effectively saved 2,150 jobs by continuing to operate in administration. 

It would have been easier and less controversial to do what other resource companies have done and just closed operations and not be concerned about more than 2,000 families that depend on our operations.

We recently celebrated 40 years in operation in Townsville and I firmly believe QN is capable of operating for another 40 years. QN can emerge from this administration as a stronger company.

The reports in the Press about the management team are untrue. I hope the administration will properly investigate and deal with these matters. I have refrained from public comment and have not attended this meeting as, like many, I am a creditor of the Company. 

I, and our shareholders, wanted all creditors including the workforce to feel free to raise any concern they may have with the administrators without being in any way restricted by my or our shareholders presence at the meeting. The operations are ongoing and employ over 550 people and impact another 1,600 jobs in Townsville. Queensland Nickel must continue to provide the security for our community to function.

On a personal note how anyone could attack the strong commitment Clive Palmer has shown to Townsville since 2009 is difficult to understand. He invested his money to save our operations when no one else would. In good times he gave away 55 Mercedes Benz and over 1,300 overseas holidays to staff. While 237 jobs have been lost because of low nickel prices, we are trying to save over 2,000 jobs. I don't see anyone else trying save jobs in North Queensland.

ENDS

I have pledged over $200m of my own assets to help keep the refinery operating and employing people in Townsville.

Media release

Shorten shorts out over Turnbull lead

In a desperate move to try to regain relevance following serious lapses of memory in the Royal Commission into trade union corruption, former National Secretary of the AWU Bill Shorten is visiting Townsville to shift blame from the AWU for not supporting workers at Queensland Nickel, Clive Palmer, the leader of the Palmer United Party in the House of Representatives, said in Canberra today.

"Ben Swan and the AWU refused to pressure the Labor State Government to provide support to enable Queensland Nickel to continue to employ its full workforce in Townsville,’’ Mr Palmer said.

“In 2009 BHP was going sack 100 percent of the workforce when the nickel price was $7.  Now it's $3.80 and because of the good work the company has implemented, it is still in production providing 550 jobs for its employees and an additional 1600 jobs in Townsville.

"It was the Labor Premier and the three Labor State Members in Townsville that refused to even meet with the management of Queensland Nickel despite the fact that Queensland Nickel is the largest employer in North Queensland and had spent over four billion dollars in North Queensland since 2009,’’ he said.

"While companies outside Queensland Nickel have provided $250 million dollars in assets as security to support QNI and workers’ entitlements, the Queensland Labor Government has offered nothing other than advice on how to fill in applications for jobs that don't exist.

“Bill Shorten and his AWU are a disgrace. They have done nothing for 22,000 jobs lost in Queensland.

“Shorten should go back to the Commission and tell them the truth about the AWU and its corruption which puts workers’ interests last.

“I challenge the Premier to match my support for the company and put up or shut up.  She just doesn't understand business or care about workers. The last thing Townsville needs is politicians grandstanding over workers’ misfortune,’’ Mr Palmer said.

ENDS

Palmer Coolum Resort and the Presidents Club

COOLUM Palmer Resort will be reactivated as a functioning tourism hub as soon as issues relating to Clive Palmer's dispute with President's Club unit owners are resolved.

Mr Palmer said he was hopeful matters could be resolved within six months but has made clear there will be no closure of the matter until the club was restructured as a body corporate, saying it was now functioning illegally.

"The President's Club on March 13, 2012 lost its ASIC approval to operate as a time share placing the way it now acts in breach of the Corporations Act.

At the same time the Ambassador's Club lost its exemption and is now a body corporate.

Shareholders have access, can stay, sell or do what they like.

In contrast the President's Club wanted the resort to act with it in breach of the Corporation law.

We refused to do that because it would be unlawful.

We will go back to court. They should be restructuring as a body corporate then everyone would have access to their units.

They haven't paid for power and water and owe us $500,000.

No-one gets power and water for free. But that's a separate issue.

We can't work with or be part of an illegal time share. If they re-organise as the Ambassador's Club has done there is no problem.

If they pay for their power and water then they can get it.

The directors of the President's Club have raised millions from unit owners and paid themselves tens of thousands of dollars a year. It's in their interests to promote the dispute.

When I purchased the refinery, the Nickel price was $7 per pound. Its now $3.80. The cost to produce the Nickel was over $8 and we have reduced this to $4 which has enabled the refinery to keep operating and keep people in jobs for the last 6 years.
